user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_open_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_open_generic(const char *name, size_t size,
			     struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem;
	struct metal_list *node;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list, node) {
		shmem = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_generic_shmem, node);
		if (strcmp(shmem->name, name) != 0)
			continue;
		if (size <= metal_io_region_size(&shmem->io)) {
			*result = &shmem->io;
			return 0;
		}
	}

	return -ENOENT;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_shmem_open_generic:
#define metal_list_for_each(list, node) for((node)=(list)->next;(node)!=(list);(node)=(node)->next)
...
#define metal_container_of(ptr, structure, member) (void*)((uintptr_t)(ptr)-metal_offset_of(structure,member))
...
struct metal_list {
	struct metal_list *next, *prev;
}
...
struct metal_generic_shmem {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_io_region	io;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
...
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
...
extern struct metal_state _metal
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No language compiler extensions are used in the provided code fragments. Reasoning:

- The metal_list_for_each macro expands to a standard for loop using pointer members; it does not use any compiler-specific extensions (no statement expressions, no typeof, no __attribute__, no inline asm, etc.).

- The metal_container_of macro uses standard casts and integer-pointer arithmetic via uintptr_t and a metal_offset_of macro; as presented it does not contain GCC/Clang-specific extensions such as typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), __builtin_* intrinsics, or __attribute__ annotations. (If metal_offset_of were implemented using an extension, that definition would need review, but it is not shown here.)

- Struct definitions (metal_list, metal_generic_shmem, metal_io_region) use only standard C struct syntax and standard types; there are no bit-field oddities, unnamed members, or compiler-specific attributes shown.

- The function metal_shmem_open_generic itself uses standard C constructs: declarations, a for-loop (via the macro), strcmp, pointer comparisons, size_t, and returns integer error codes (e.g. -ENOENT). None of these are compiler language extensions.

If there are other macro/utility definitions (for example the actual implementation of metal_offset_of) not shown here, those should be inspected for use of compiler-specific extensions; based on the provided code fragments, however, there are no explicit language extensions to report.
